title: How to Protect a Wall When Painting a Downpipe

steps.headline: Cut a piece of box or thick cardboard about the size of a calendar.
steps.description: The piece of cardboard that comes inside calendars is ideal and does not need pre-cutting.

steps.headline: Place this piece of cardboard between the downpipe and the wall.
steps.description: You can either pin it up using tape or sticky tack, or you can hold it if it isn't too difficult to hold and paint.

steps.headline: Paint the area of the downpipe over the piece of cardboard.
steps.description: Start at the top and work your way down the pipe towards the ground level.

steps.headline: Shift the cardboard as each section is completed.
steps.description: Move the piece of cardboard down and paint each new section until you finish painting the entire downpipe.

text: Cut a piece of box or thick cardboard about the size of a calendar. The piece of cardboard that comes inside calendars is ideal and does not need pre-cutting. Place this piece of cardboard between the downpipe and the wall. You can either pin it up using tape or sticky tack, or you can hold it if it isn't too difficult to hold and paint. Paint the area of the downpipe over the piece of cardboard. Start at the top and work your way down the pipe towards the ground level. Shift the cardboard as each section is completed. Move the piece of cardboard down and paint each new section until you finish painting the entire downpipe. Leave to dry. The wall should be paint-free.
